trans-unit.source: Visual Studio tools for game programming
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio tools for game programming

trans-unit.source: An overview of DirectX specific tools available in Visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: An overview of DirectX specific tools available in Visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio tools for game programming
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio tools for game programming

trans-unit.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

trans-unit.source: Summary
trans-unit.target: Summary

trans-unit.source: Create a DirectX game project from a template
trans-unit.target: Create a DirectX game project from a template

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio tools for DirectX game programming
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio tools for DirectX game programming

trans-unit.source: If you use Visual Studio Ultimate to develop DirectX apps, there are additional tools available for creating, editing, previewing, and exporting image, model, and shader resources.
trans-unit.target: If you use Visual Studio Ultimate to develop DirectX apps, there are additional tools available for creating, editing, previewing, and exporting image, model, and shader resources.

trans-unit.source: There are also tools that you can use to convert resources at build time and debug DirectX graphics code.
trans-unit.target: There are also tools that you can use to convert resources at build time and debug DirectX graphics code.

trans-unit.source: This topic gives an overview of these graphics tools.
trans-unit.target: This topic gives an overview of these graphics tools.

trans-unit.source: Image Editor
trans-unit.target: Image Editor

trans-unit.source: Use the Image Editor to work with the kinds of rich texture and image formats that DirectX uses.
trans-unit.target: Use the Image Editor to work with the kinds of rich texture and image formats that DirectX uses.

trans-unit.source: The Image Editor supports the following formats.
trans-unit.target: The Image Editor supports the following formats.

trans-unit.source: .png
trans-unit.target: .png

trans-unit.source: .jpg, .jpeg, .jpe, .jfif
trans-unit.target: .jpg, .jpeg, .jpe, .jfif

trans-unit.source: .dds
trans-unit.target: .dds

trans-unit.source: .gif
trans-unit.target: .gif

trans-unit.source: .bmp
trans-unit.target: .bmp

trans-unit.source: .dib
trans-unit.target: .dib

trans-unit.source: .tif, .tiff
trans-unit.target: .tif, .tiff

trans-unit.source: .tga
trans-unit.target: .tga

trans-unit.source: Create [build customization files](#custom) to convert these to .dds files at build time.
trans-unit.target: Create [build customization files](#custom) to convert these to .dds files at build time.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Working with Textures and Images](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/hh873119.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Working with Textures and Images](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/hh873119.aspx).

trans-unit.source: **Note** The Image Editor is not intended to be a replacement for a full feature image editing app, but is appropriate for many simple viewing and editing scenarios.
trans-unit.target: **Note** The Image Editor is not intended to be a replacement for a full feature image editing app, but is appropriate for many simple viewing and editing scenarios.

trans-unit.source: Model Editor
trans-unit.target: Model Editor

trans-unit.source: You can use the Model Editor to create basic 3D models from scratch, or to view and modify more-complex 3D models from full-featured 3D modeling tools.
trans-unit.target: You can use the Model Editor to create basic 3D models from scratch, or to view and modify more-complex 3D models from full-featured 3D modeling tools.

trans-unit.source: The Model Editor supports several 3D model formats that are used in DirectX app development.
trans-unit.target: The Model Editor supports several 3D model formats that are used in DirectX app development.

trans-unit.source: You can create [build customization files](#custom) to convert these to .cmo files at build time.
trans-unit.target: You can create [build customization files](#custom) to convert these to .cmo files at build time.

trans-unit.source: .fbx
trans-unit.target: .fbx

trans-unit.source: .dae
trans-unit.target: .dae

trans-unit.source: .obj
trans-unit.target: .obj

trans-unit.source: Here's a screenshot of a model in the editor with lighting applied.
trans-unit.target: Here's a screenshot of a model in the editor with lighting applied.

trans-unit.source: teapot
trans-unit.target: teapot

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Working with 3-D Models](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/hh873114.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Working with 3-D Models](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/hh873114.aspx).

trans-unit.source: **Note** The Model Editor is not intended to be a replacement for a full feature model editing app, but is appropriate for many simple viewing and editing scenarios.
trans-unit.target: **Note** The Model Editor is not intended to be a replacement for a full feature model editing app, but is appropriate for many simple viewing and editing scenarios.

trans-unit.source: Shader Designer
trans-unit.target: Shader Designer

trans-unit.source: Use the Shader Designer to create custom visual effects for your game or app even if you don't know HLSL programming.
trans-unit.target: Use the Shader Designer to create custom visual effects for your game or app even if you don't know HLSL programming.

trans-unit.source: You create a shader visually as a graph.
trans-unit.target: You create a shader visually as a graph.

trans-unit.source: Each node displays a preview of the output up to that operation.
trans-unit.target: Each node displays a preview of the output up to that operation.

trans-unit.source: Here's an example that applies Lambert lighting with a sphere preview.
trans-unit.target: Here's an example that applies Lambert lighting with a sphere preview.

trans-unit.source: visual shader graph
trans-unit.target: visual shader graph

trans-unit.source: Use the Shader Editor to design, edit, and save shaders in the .dgsl format.
trans-unit.target: Use the Shader Editor to design, edit, and save shaders in the .dgsl format.

trans-unit.source: It also exports the following formats.
trans-unit.target: It also exports the following formats.

trans-unit.source: .hlsl (source code)
trans-unit.target: .hlsl (source code)

trans-unit.source: .cso (bytecode)
trans-unit.target: .cso (bytecode)

trans-unit.source: .h (HLSL bytecode array)
trans-unit.target: .h (HLSL bytecode array)

trans-unit.source: Create [build customization files](#custom) to convert any of these formats to .cso files at build time.
trans-unit.target: Create [build customization files](#custom) to convert any of these formats to .cso files at build time.

trans-unit.source: Here is a portion of HLSL code that is exported by the Shader Editor.
trans-unit.target: Here is a portion of HLSL code that is exported by the Shader Editor.

trans-unit.source: This is only the code for the Lambert lighting node.
trans-unit.target: This is only the code for the Lambert lighting node.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Working with Shaders](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/hh873117.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Working with Shaders](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/hh873117.aspx).

trans-unit.source: Build customizations for 3D assets
trans-unit.target: Build customizations for 3D assets

trans-unit.source: You can add build customizations to your project so that Visual Studio converts resources to usable formats.
trans-unit.target: You can add build customizations to your project so that Visual Studio converts resources to usable formats.

trans-unit.source: After that, you can load the assets into your app and use them by creating and filling DirectX resources just like you would in any other DirectX app.
trans-unit.target: After that, you can load the assets into your app and use them by creating and filling DirectX resources just like you would in any other DirectX app.

trans-unit.source: To add a build customization, you right-click on the project in the **Solution Explorer** and select **Build Customizations...**.
trans-unit.target: To add a build customization, you right-click on the project in the **Solution Explorer** and select **Build Customizations...**.

trans-unit.source: You can add the following types of build customizations to your project.
trans-unit.target: You can add the following types of build customizations to your project.

trans-unit.source: Image Content Pipeline takes image files as input and outputs DirectDraw Surface (.dds) files.
trans-unit.target: Image Content Pipeline takes image files as input and outputs DirectDraw Surface (.dds) files.

trans-unit.source: Mesh Content Pipeline takes mesh files (such as .fbx) and outputs .cmo mesh files.
trans-unit.target: Mesh Content Pipeline takes mesh files (such as .fbx) and outputs .cmo mesh files.

trans-unit.source: Shader Content Pipeline takes Visual Shader Graph (.dgsl) from the Visual Studio Shader Editor and outputs a Compiled Shader Output (.cso) file.
trans-unit.target: Shader Content Pipeline takes Visual Shader Graph (.dgsl) from the Visual Studio Shader Editor and outputs a Compiled Shader Output (.cso) file.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Using 3-D Assets in Your Game or App](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/hh972446.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Using 3-D Assets in Your Game or App](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/hh972446.aspx).

trans-unit.source: Debugging DirectX graphics
trans-unit.target: Debugging DirectX graphics

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio provides graphics-specific debugging tools.
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio provides graphics-specific debugging tools.

trans-unit.source: Use these tools to debug things like:
trans-unit.target: Use these tools to debug things like:

trans-unit.source: The graphics pipeline.
trans-unit.target: The graphics pipeline.

trans-unit.source: The event call stack.
trans-unit.target: The event call stack.

trans-unit.source: The object table.
trans-unit.target: The object table.

trans-unit.source: The device state.
trans-unit.target: The device state.

trans-unit.source: Shader bugs.
trans-unit.target: Shader bugs.

trans-unit.source: Uninitialized or incorrect constant buffers and parameters.
trans-unit.target: Uninitialized or incorrect constant buffers and parameters.

trans-unit.source: DirectX version compatibility.
trans-unit.target: DirectX version compatibility.

trans-unit.source: Limited Direct2D support.
trans-unit.target: Limited Direct2D support.

trans-unit.source: Operating system and SDK requirements.
trans-unit.target: Operating system and SDK requirements.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Debugging DirectX Graphics](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/hh315751.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Debugging DirectX Graphics](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/hh315751.aspx).

trans-unit.source: **Note** This article is for Windows 10 developers writing Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps.
trans-unit.target: **Note** This article is for Windows 10 developers writing Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps.

trans-unit.source: If you’re developing for Windows 8.x or Windows Phone 8.x, see the [archived documentation](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?linkid=619132).
trans-unit.target: If you’re developing for Windows 8.x or Windows Phone 8.x, see the [archived documentation](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?linkid=619132).
